title: [Android][iOS] Separate Interpreter Lib Asserts When Used

author: BrzVlad
body:
The interpreter instruction stream is an array of `ushort`. This data type is used to store most of the common data, from opcode, offsets, static data indexes etc. In some uncommon scenarios, for large methods, we can hit this limit.

- [ ] Most instructions have source and destination offsets. Methods with many locals can have this space overflowed. Currently we throw `Unable to run method: locals size too big.`. Tests hitting this are `JIT/jit64/opt/cse/HugeArray1` and  `JIT/Regression/JitBlue/GitHub_21990`
- [ ] Some instructions contain embedded offsets that are expected to fit in an `ushort` (for example `MINT_LDFLD`, `MINT_STFLD`). Test hitting this `JIT/Regression/JitBlue/Runtime_34170`
- [ ] A method has more than 64k data_items. https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/59221

nodes.body:

Issue Details
When encountering a method with a large enough local space, the compiler will throw `Unable to run method: locals size too big.`

title: Mono interpreter has a general limit of 64k for offsets and indexes

author: BrzVlad
body:
Following https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/43681 and https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/46037, the interpreter allows for additional improvements. This issue tracks additional improvements that we plan to do, loosely ordered by their priority. This list will be updated with additional improvements that are deemed useful.

## Optimizations Done

- [x] Enable inlining of methods that throw exceptions https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/48513
- [x] Add our own var offset allocator, moving away from the current one based on IL stack. This improves the flexibility of future optimizations. https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/49072
- [x] Optimize MINT_NEWOBJ opcodes. Remove memcpy of args, allow for optimizing them out. https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/49072
- [x] Add superinstructions for binop + imm, also for ret + imm https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/50361
- [x] Additional superinstructions and optimizations https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/51273
- [x] Remove abort protection of finally blocks https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/51309
- [x] Remove MINT_CHECKPOINT generation. Add superinstructions for branches https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/52130
- [x] Optimize passing of global call arguments https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/52242
- [x] Replace compare + brtrue/brfalse pattern with binop conditional branch https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/79215 and https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/80046
- [x] Fix bblock removal to account for loops https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/79215
- [x] Vector128 SIMD intrinsics https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/81782
- [x] Implement SSA so we can more easily implement most of the optimizations below https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/96315
- [x] Track the value of global vars over multiple basic blocks https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/96315
- [x] Remove uses of MINT_INITLOCALS, since almost every local is initialized explicitly by code https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/96315

## Planned optimizations

- [ ] Loop unrolling
- [ ] Struct field promotion
- [ ] Constant propagation of string literals
- [ ] Move constant declaration from common paths to their use location
- [ ] Improve inlining heuristic
- [ ] Additional hardware / numerics intrinsics
- [ ] Optimize out unnecessary MINT_CKNULL, by tracking nullability of some vars
- [ ] Optimize out empty finally blocks
- [ ] Loop-invariant hoisting
- [ ] Better track type of vars and remove redundant CONV opcodes

Following https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/43681 and https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/46037, the interpreter allows for additional improvements. This issue tracks additional improvements that we plan to do, loosely ordered by their priority. This list will be updated with additional improvements that are deemed useful. ## Planned optimizations - [ ] Add our own var offset allocator, moving away from the current one based on IL stack. This improves the flexibility of future optimizations. - [ ] Optimize MINT_NEWOBJ opcodes. Remove memcpy of args, allow for optimizing them out. - [ ] Add superinstructions for binop + imm, also for ret + imm - [ ] Remove MINT_CHECKPOINT generation. Either include the checkpoint into all branching opcodes, or add a few superinstructions for the most common branching opcodes. - [ ] Optimize out unnecessary MINT_CKNULL, by tracking nullability of some vars - [ ] Optimize out empty finally blocks - [ ] Enable inlining of methods that throw exceptions - [ ] Track the value of global vars over multiple basic blocks - [ ] Remove uses of MINT_INITLOCALS, since almost every local is initialized explicitly by code.

title: Mono interpreter performance optimizations

author: vargaz

nodes.body: I couldn't figure out the best area label to add to this issue. If you have write-permissions please help me learn by adding exactly one [area label](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/area-owners.md).

Tagging subscribers to this area: @brzvlad See info in area-owners.md if you want to be subscribed.
Issue Details
Testcase: ``` using System; class P { static void Main() { try { throw new Exception(); } catch (Exception) when (Throw()) { Console.WriteLine("Unreached"); } catch (Exception) { Console.WriteLine("Works as expected"); } } static bool Throw() { throw new Exception(); } } ``` To reproduce: ``` mono --interp bug.exe ``` Expected result: ``` Unhandled Exception: System.Exception: Exception of type 'System.Exception' was thrown. ``` Actual result: ``` at (wrapper runtime-invoke) object.runtime_invoke_direct_void (object,intptr,intptr,intptr) <0x000c6> at <0xffffffff> at P/Q.Throw () <0x00028> at P/Q.Main () <0x00036> at P/Q.Main () <0x00012> at (wrapper runtime-invoke) object.runtime_invoke_direct_void (object,intptr,intptr,intptr) <0x000c6> at <0xffffffff> .... ```
Author: vargaz
Assignees: BrzVlad
Labels: `area-Codegen-Interpreter-mono`, `untriaged`
Milestone: -

nodes.author: vargaz
nodes.body: It looks like the try-catch catches the exception thrown by the Throw () from inside the filter.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: @vargaz Did you spend some time thinking about this issue ? I'm not sure it is worth making interp throw like jit since that is wrong behavior. And fixing the behavior altogether seems like a non trivial fix. We need to catch all exceptions thrown from invoking a filter clause. I think we would need a new wrapper that is capable of invoking a filter clause in a method (we would need a new MONO_CEE_ opcode that does this and use it in the wrapper) and runtime invoke into it. While this sounds fair to implement on interpreter, having this working on all JIT targets sounds like a pain. Maybe I can implement this on interp and jit can catch up later with support for this wrapper. Any other better ideas ?

nodes.author: vargaz
nodes.body: I think the problem is that the somehow the catch/filter clause catches the exception thrown from the filter itself i.e. the EH code thinks execution is still in the try block.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: Exceptions thrown by filters should be ignored. So even if interp doesn't catch the exception by mistake there, the exception will still bubble up and kill the application which is incorrect behavior (this is what JIT is doing now)

nodes.author: vargaz
nodes.body: In .net, it looks like if a filter clause throws, it's treated as returning false.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
This is what ECMA says about **endfilter**: `If
an exception is thrown inside the filter block, it is intercepted and a value of
exception_continue_search is returned.`. So our current implementation is wrong anyway, both on interpreter and jit.

nodes.author: SamMonoRT
nodes.body: We'll work on this, but not targeting 7.0.0

title: Mono interpreter gets into infinite recursion on filter clause

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body: We should look at this one for .NET 6 - we don't really expect benchmark code to fail.  Maybe the test just takes a long time with interp on Android and it's getting killed?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: I don't believe this is a bug in the runtime. The test runs just fine on desktop.

nodes.author: fanyang-mono
nodes.body: Then, this test may have some issue running on Android. I will take a look later.

nodes.author: fanyang-mono
nodes.body: Moving to 8.0.0

Tagging subscribers to 'arch-android': @steveisok, @akoeplinger

title: [MONO][Interp] Loader/classloader/* tests failed on Android x64 with interpreter

author: lambdageek
body:
See https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/59220.  In that PR we addressed particular machine-generated methods that only had `ldc`, `ldsfld` and `stsfld` instructions.  But in general if a method gets large enough and it may use more than 64k data items.

There are a number of approaches we could investigate - depending on the solution complexity and the impact on interpreter performance:

* We could use 32-bit data item indices in general
* We could add `.w` variants for every opcode.
* We could use a variable-length encoding of the data item index (and get variable-length instructions in general).
* We could add a new `data.item.base` instruction that let's us specify a 32-bit base data item address before any opcode that needs access to data items with index > 64k.  (we will also need to validate that all the items an opcode needs are within 64k of the base).
* We could reserve the top bit of a data item index to indicate some kind of indirection (maybe to a preceeding "nop.with.data" instruction that has the full 32-bit index).
* Something else

nodes.author: kotlarmilos
nodes.body:
The failing test creates a new object of a struct and attempts to change its value through a reference while a pointer to the object is still on the stack. The test expects that the value shouldn't be changed as the object pointer is still on the stack, so any changes made via the reference shouldn't affect the temporary object on the stack but local "copy".


In the optimized interpreter code, the instruction "ldc.i4 THRASHED" shouldn't change the value in the struct, but rather its local "copy". Later, the instruction "ldfld int32 Struct::Value" should load "EXPECTED," not "TRASHED."

```
Runtime method: Runtime_74635:ProblemWithCapturingCtors () 0x16fdfcb98
Locals size 80
Calculated stack height: 4, stated height: 8
IR_0000: initlocals     [nil <- nil], 0,16
IR_0003: ldc.i4.0       [56 <- nil],
IR_0005: ldloca.s       [64 <- nil], 0
IR_0008: newobj_vt      [16 <- 48], 0
IR_000d: mov.vt         [24 <- 0], 8
IR_0011: mov.8          [24 <- 24],
IR_0014: ldc.i4.1       [32 <- nil],
IR_0016: stfld.i4       [nil <- 24 32], 0
IR_001a: mov.4          [16 <- 16],
IR_001d: bne.un.i4.imm.sp [nil <- 16], 0, IR_0023
IR_0021: ret.i4.imm     [nil <- nil], 0
IR_0023: ret.i4.imm     [nil <- nil], 1
```

If we wanted to support this behavior in the interpreter, it would need to keep a copy of the `newobj instance void Struct::.ctor(int32, valuetype Closure&)` instance until it is popped from the stack, and any changes made in between should not affect the copy version. Such an approach could require significant changes in the codebase, as interpreter doesn't create temporary instances when creating an object. If this particular test is not a customer issue but rather an edge case, then I suggest enabling other tests for interpreter and excluding `ProblemWithCapturingCtors` test.

@SingleAccretion Could you please confirm if this particular test has been reported as a customer issue? If it hasn't, we could exclude the "ProblemWithCapturingCtors" test from the current project and create a separate project to run it on all platforms except for the Interpreter. 

If confirmed, I would proceed with a PR.

nodes.author: SingleAccretion
nodes.body:
> Could you please confirm if this particular test has been reported as a customer issue?

It indeed was not; the test is meant to stress the correctness of the spilling logic in RyuJit's importer in the face of tricky aliasing (specifically, I originally thought `newobj` locals could be marked "not aliased", so it was written to disprove this). The [original issue](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/74635#issuecomment-1235089172) was also in test code.

I am not sure how much value there is in splitting the projects, since the other tests are somewhat RyuJit-specific, but will leave that up to you.

FWIW, RyuJit does create unique temporaries for `newobj`s due to issues like this.

nodes.author: kotlarmilos
nodes.body: Thank you. Improving test coverage on the Interpreter is important, but as you mentioned it could lead to unnecessary complexity. Is there a way to disable the specific test on the Interpreter, while enabling others and keeping them in the same file? If not, then we could close this issue for now and revisit it in the future, if necessary.

nodes.author: SingleAccretion
nodes.body:
> Is there a way to disable the specific test on the Interpreter, while enabling others and keeping them in the same file? 

Dynamic checks come to mind.

Another possibility is to put the test under an `#ifdef MONO_INTERPRETER` and then include a file with `#define MONO_INTERPRETER` conditionally (in the project).

title: Mono interpreter doesn't handle mutating `newobj` values through aliases

author: SteveSandersonMS

nodes.body: I couldn't figure out the best area label to add to this issue. If you have write-permissions please help me learn by adding exactly one [area label](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/area-owners.md).

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: Thanks for the testcase. This area was never really addressed in the interpreter. I plan to work on improving HW intrinsics / vector operations for .net 8.

nodes.author: vargaz
tannergooding
nodes.body:
> This probably happens because the fallback code for the vector operations is written assuming an optimizing compiler, like for Max():

It's not written assuming an optimizing compiler. It's written to ensure the code can be easily maintained.

We ultimately have 12 types we have to support for each operation and are working in a generic context. We can either have simple implementations like this, or methods which are hundreds of lines long and manually unrolling everything.

Regardless of optimization support or not, that much code is not maintainable and adds additional risk and bug opportunities and is not something we are going to check in. An optimizing compiler "can" do the right thing here (such as unrolling or simple inlining), but a non-optimizing compiler will have just as many (if not more) problems with the alternative larger implementation. 

Ultimately, an optimizing compiler should prefer intrinsic recognition and transformation of these exact methods directly to the corresponding SIMD operation. Something like an AOT compiler should recognize the existing and fairly standardized coding patterns around generics (e.g. the `typeof(T) == typeof(...)` checks) and do the basic dead code optimization.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
I took a quick look at this testcase. I find it hard to believe that these numbers were actually real for interpreter. Currently on main, for this testcase, on desktop, vectorized path is about 3-4 times slower, on wasm it is normally about 4-5 slower. However jiterp makes the vectorized path actually 3 times faster than non-vectorized path (I assume v8 has something to do with optimizing our bad jitted code).

We added actual vector 128 support but some of the use cases have no support planned yet, like for floats, since they are not really used internally in the BCL.

On interpreter, the vectorized path would get a significant boost once we implement loop unrolling, maybe for .NET 9. Keeping this open to check again afterwards.

title: tracing/runtimeeventsource/nativeruntimeeventsource/nativeruntimeeventsource.sh Timed Out on Mono OSX x64 with interpreter

author: kg

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body: As of https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/94446/commits/3a278eeb7c046ffe12ffbfeb6f955f382f51667a in #94446 basic cases now work in the interpreter, I had to fix some assumptions about scalarized structs (i.e. they're always int32) and also update the return value marshaling to handle scalarized return values. Will investigate AOT more.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
The AOT wrapper appears to invoke using the wrong indirect signature when structs are involved. For a pinvoke with the signature 'float (double)', it's correct:
```
75336 117100    call_indirect 113 tables[0] s(d)
```

For a pinvoke accepting a struct and returning a float:
```
75201 11D70100  call_indirect 215 tables[0] s(l)
```

For a pinvoke accepting a struct and returning a struct:
```
75067 115300    call_indirect 83 tables[0] i(l)
```

It looks like the problem is it's picking an appropriately-sized int to contain the struct, but in this case it needs to pick an appropriately-sized float instead.

author: akoeplinger
body:
After https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/97192 was merged we started seeing timeouts in System.Numerics.Tensors.Tests on Mono across all platforms, but seemingly only when using the JIT. Interpreter runs pass fine.

There are a large number of long-running tests like this, but disabling them one-by-one wasn't helpful since then just another test was hanging so I had to disable the whole test project

```

[Long Running Test] 'System.Numerics.Tensors.Tests.HalfGenericTensorPrimitives.IndexOfMax_ReturnsNegative1OnEmpty', Elapsed: 00:02:03
```

nodes.author: Nemo-G
nodes.body:
I'm going to provide more info here. I located the method to marshal and turned on `MONO_VERBOSE_METHOD`. 
And I hacked in `interp_local_deadce` like 
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/assets/4470810/a632eeeb-1a6a-4e95-806c-ca3bf98baf64)

Here's the IL diff containing jiterp&bblocks ON vs OFF. 
https://www.diffchecker.com/4MXLTBTw/

It seems certain instructions was taken as dead but should be kept? And the mis-removal would cause problem in jiterp optimization? 

In fact, with the hacking above. The program would work with only JITERP disabled

@BrzVlad I completely understand that you might be swamped. But would you take a look and provide some insights when you have time? Thanks in advance!

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
Thank you for taking the time to look into it. From the verbose log, it looks like the ldloca is generated with the incorrect source. The `prefix1` instruction from inlined method is most likely a `ldarga`. All roads point to this being a known issue: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/97650.

Are you sure you are using the latest net8 release ?

nodes.author: Nemo-G
nodes.body: @BrzVlad Thanks for the inputs! We are indeed not working on the latest net8 but a fork with Unity specific changes. I will apply the patch and get you with the results later.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: There have been some serious changes in this area in .net9. It would be worthwhile to try it out. Maybe @kg can provide some help with diagnosing this latest failure

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body: As a starting point, you could use MONO_VERBOSE_METHOD to dump IsUserCattrProvider. The jiterpreter should automatically engage its diagnostics for the method and we can examine what it's doing to see if it makes sense.

nodes.author: Nemo-G
kg
nodes.body:
Is there a reason why it says `dotnet.runtime.8.0.0.90q4mwuy84.js`? Are you not able to use the latest version of 8.0?
Will still investigate, but you may be missing bug fixes.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
Also, are you running any third party WASM code in your environment? This crash appears to indicate memory corruption, specifically the reserved low memory region in the WASM heap that's supposed to be all zeroes. If the low memory region is corrupted when the jiterpreter is enabled, that can turn NullReferenceExceptions into 'memory access out of bounds' errors. I refer to this area as the "zero page".

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/assets/198130/d5587ea2-2c40-446d-9cda-b6fa1e5d28c2)

If the zero page is being corrupted, you can disable zero page optimizations by turning off the `jiterpreter-zero-page-optimization` option. See https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/mono/jiterpreter.md#configuring-the-jiterpreter for information on how to configure the jiterpreter.

You could also disable null check elimination, but in this case I don't think that's related.

If I found the correct implementation of `IsUserCattrProvider`, this would potentially occur if the `obj` passed into it is not a `Type`. The first isinst will produce null, and the second isinst will be type-checking null (which is safe with zero page optimizations as long as the heap isn't corrupted).

You could also examine the bottom of WASM memory in the devtools debugger when this crash happens. It should be all zeroes.

nodes.author: Nemo-G
nodes.body:
@kg Yes there are third party natives, I'm working on Unity :) My team started to add a lot Unity specific changes on top of NET8 to make it work on WebGL platform without AOT (to keep a lower memory on mobile devices).  In fact this issue comes from one of our clients. As we need a stable version and not sure if any recurssion issue may be introduced when applying the latest change of NET8, we just let the net8 stay on a specific version unless there are problems. And only the wasm changes are necessary for us.

I will try the jiterp options first and try to merge the latest NET8 later.

nodes.author: Nemo-G
nodes.body: Confirmed that there is no MOOB when `jiterpreter-zero-page-optimization` is turned off.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
> Confirmed that there is no MOOB when `jiterpreter-zero-page-optimization` is turned off.

For the interim it should be safe to just run with that option turned off, and the performance penalty is pretty small (something like 1-5% for jiterpreter traces that do specific operations).

nodes.author: Nemo-G
nodes.body:
> For the interim it should be safe to just run with that option turned off, and the performance penalty is pretty small (something like 1-5% for jiterpreter traces that do specific operations).

Will try that temporarily for this specific project. Thanks for the help!
But from your analysis, it seems there is an NPE which corrupts the 'zeroPage'. Instead of disabling the zero page opts, is there an 'official way' to solve this problem? I mean in what directions that I can try to analyze further? If there are other solutions, I definitely do not want to disable zero page opts by default for every clients.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
I do not know of any good way to detect zero page corruption other than frequently verifying the zero page after invoking third party code. The jiterpreter does some basic checks of the zero page in order to identify this kind of corruption, and it will shut off the optimizations if it detects it. But it can't always detect it.

Also, I believe we pass `--low-memory-unused` to `wasm-opt` when optimizing the runtime, so the runtime itself may end up containing similar zero page optimizations in its C. I'm not sure when or how `wasm-opt` exploits this property. I think clang may also have some optimizations of this sort in it. So you may potentially experience related crashes in other code.

nodes.author: Nemo-G
nodes.body:
You are correct. I just checked the build binlog and found that `-O3 --low-memory-unused --zero-filled-memory...` were passed to `wasm-opt`. 

As for the 3rd party codes, except for Unity engine native modules, 3rd party native libs are allowed to be involved in the build process. If this crash can be triggered by any 3rd party native(wasm), it seems disabling the zero page optimization would be the only way to ensure the game won't crash.

title: [Mono][Wasm][Interp] Assertion fail in Marshal.GetFunctionPointerForDelegate

author: SingleAccretion
body:
Reproduction:
```
> dotnet new wasmconsole
```
```cs
using System;
using System.Runtime.InteropServices;

public unsafe class Program
{
    public static void Main()
    {
        nint fptr = Marshal.GetFunctionPointerForDelegate(new Action(() => Console.WriteLine("Managed method callee")));
        ((delegate* unmanaged<void>)fptr)();
    }
}
```

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
This particular crash is caused by a failure to obtain the managed method associated with a native to managed wrapper. However, even if we were to fix this, the testcase couldn't possible work on wasm interp nowadays. This is because, in order to obtain a ftnptr for entering execution of a method with interpreter, we require a thunk that receives all arguments of the call and calls into interpreter while passing an additional argument, the interp method to execute. Currently, these thunks are generated during app compilation, by build tasks in `PInvokeTableGenerator.cs`, only for methods with `UnmanagedCallersOnly` attribute. Given `Marshal.GetFunctionPointerForDelegate` requires a delegate, which I don't think can be created for a method with `UnmanagedCallersOnly` attribute, this API can't work on wasm interp.

I think a fix for this would be to completely stop relying, if possible, on the pinvoke table generator and always generate these thunks on the fly with the wasm jit support. Was this already brought into discussion ? @lewing @kg

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
I think I've raised the possibility of jitting trampolines for this in browser WASM before but we've never had a discussion about whether to do it or when.

It seems like we could do it on android too (do we already?) but couldn't do it on iOS or wasi.

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body:
There are some separate issues here:

1. we're running strlen on a null string instead of throwing PNSE like it used to
2. on browser we could jit trampolines, should we?
3. on wasi we could do something terrible hacks with preallocating pools by signature if we really needed to

I would definitely like to fix 1.

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: I need to verify that this throws an exception rather than crashing now.

title: [Mono/WASM] `Marshal.GetFunctionPointerForDelegate` crashes the runtime

author: jonathanpeppers
body:
### Description

I'm investigating an app that is very slow in Debug mode:

* https://github.com/dotnet/maui/issues/23991
* https://github.com/chabiss/periodictable

Note that Debug mode on Android:
* Uses interpreter for C# hot reload
* No trimmer, no AOT
* No XAML compilation, so XAML is parsed
* `$(Optimize)` C# compiler setting, etc.

Those are a lot of reasons this is generally, slower.

I think I narrowed down to a basic Java interop method that showcases one slowdown under interp:

```csharp
[MethodImpl(MethodImplOptions.AggressiveInlining)]
internal unsafe static void DeleteLocalRef(nint env, nint instance)
{
    (*(JNIEnv**)env)->DeleteLocalRef(env, instance);
}

// Then the C# function pointer is
internal struct JNIEnv
{
    public unsafe delegate* unmanaged<nint, nint, void> DeleteLocalRef;
}
```

Using our latest stable releases, you can see this method:

```
Debug:
1.09s (3.0%) java.interop!Java.Interop.JniEnvironment.References.DeleteLocalRef(intptr)
Release:
274.47ms (1.0%) java.interop!Java.Interop.JniEnvironment.References.DeleteLocalRef(intptr)
```
(Note that I compared the calling method, because of aggressive inlining)

`DeleteLocalRef()` is just one instance of a slow method under interp, general Java interop will invoke many other methods like this.

Other ideas:
* Is there a way we could try to JIT some assemblies and use interp for the rest? If we used JIT for `Mono.Android.dll` and `Java.Interop.dll` those would never be C# "hot reloaded".

### Reproduction Steps

Debug the sample in VS on Android:
* https://github.com/chabiss/periodictable

### Expected behavior

Performance of `(*(JNIEnv**)env)->DeleteLocalRef(env, instance)` is reasonable in Debug mode.

### Actual behavior

Performance of `(*(JNIEnv**)env)->DeleteLocalRef(env, instance)` could be improved.

### Regression?

No, I think this was always the case.

### Known Workarounds

Disable the interpreter with `UseInterpreter=false`, or run `Release` mode.

### Configuration

> dotnet --version
8.0.400

### Other information

Here are some `dotnet-trace`'s I've recorded of this app: [debug_vs_release.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16628868/debug_vs_release.zip)

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: It is not clear to me from the report, but is the performance with interpreter acceptable in release mode ? I don't think it would be a good ideea to start mixing with aot/jit code, but I think it is feasible to support hotreload/debug in the user assemblies only and have the sdk/runtime assemblies always fully optimized.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
Will everything work if we built `libaot-Mono.Android.dll.so` / `libaot-Java.Interop.dll.so`, and tried to use these in Debug mode? We would probably try `MONO_AOT_MODE_NORMAL` initially.

The only concern is what happens if runtime has a 9.0.1 service release, for example? We don't necessarily release a new Android workload at the same time. So, would an older AOT image always work with newer runtimes?

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body:
> Will everything work if we built `libaot-Mono.Android.dll.so` / `libaot-Java.Interop.dll.so`, and tried to use these in Debug mode? We would probably try `MONO_AOT_MODE_NORMAL` initially.

Interpreter fallback currently only works in aot only scenario. We never ran aot-only on android. It is definitely logically possible but it is not trivial and it represents a new configuration to maintain that doesn't seem to have significant justification in my opinion.

> The only concern is what happens if runtime has a 9.0.1 service release, for example? We don't necessarily release a new Android workload at the same time. So, would an older AOT image always work with newer runtimes?

My understanding is that the android workload holds the versions for both the device runtime as well as for the aot cross compiler and it doesn't matter if the version is different from the desktop runtime. There can be problems if the version that is used to aot compile is different from the version at runtime.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
> There can be problems if the version that is used to aot compile is different from the version at runtime.

Yes, I think this is what would happen. Each time a new runtime is serviced, we don't necessarily ship a new Android workload. You would get new Mono packages like the AOT compiler, runtime packs, etc.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body: I don't think we will do this - I hope you agree @jonathanpeppers .

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: From what I know, interpreter under debug build can be an order of magnitude slower than interpreter with full optimizations enabled. While we probably don't want to complicate ourselves with mixing aot and interpreter on android, I think there is an opportunity for an easy good enough fix if we optimize framework assemblies only. My understanding is that the interpreter would only need to consume the `DebuggableAttribute` to determine whether to optimize a method or not.

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
This was filed a year ago, but this might be solved on other runtimes that support EnC & ReadyToRun in Debug mode.

Solving this would be specific to Mono.

author: srxqds
body:
mono interp transfer il code to opcode in `generate` function: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/1e5bae2e56180897c95ac3f9adaa5609d14d20b3/src/mono/mono/mini/interp/transform.c#L9424

the`TransformData` allocate stack at below：
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/1e5bae2e56180897c95ac3f9adaa5609d14d20b3/src/mono/mono/mini/interp/transform.c#L9501-L9508

and will store the custom data in `data_items`: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/1e5bae2e56180897c95ac3f9adaa5609d14d20b3/src/mono/mono/mini/interp/transform.c#L9476

at end of the function `generate`, I found the `opcode` or `data_items` will copy to InterpMethod in below code:

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/1e5bae2e56180897c95ac3f9adaa5609d14d20b3/src/mono/mono/mini/interp/transform.c#L9584-L9614

and copy `InterpInst`(allocated in `interp_add_ins`) at `generate_compacted_code`:

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/1e5bae2e56180897c95ac3f9adaa5609d14d20b3/src/mono/mono/mini/interp/transform.c#L9286-L9289

but I could not found the `td->stack` been copy  before being freed at :  

https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/1e5bae2e56180897c95ac3f9adaa5609d14d20b3/src/mono/mono/mini/interp/transform.c#L9675-L9688


why not these data not restore to `InterpMethod`  or maybe other place restore it?

could you help me? @BrzVlad

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: `td->stack` and `InterpInst*` is information that is used only during compilation time. The list of `InterpInst` is iterated as the last step of compilation and in `generate_compacted_code` this list is compacted into an array of `guint16` that represents the final generated code.

title: question about understand interp generate transform code

author: johnW-ret
body:
### Description

Referencing F# code that utilizes tail calls in a C# WASM app does not perform TCO at runtime and a large enough stack will result in a `StackOverflowException`.

### Reproduction Steps
See [johnW-ret/FsDataStackOverflowBug000](https://github.com/johnW-ret/FsDataStackOverflowBug000) reproduction.

1. 
   ```pwsh
   mkdir uselessdelete
   cd uselessdelete
   
   dotnet new blazorwasm -o blazor
   dotnet new classlib -o library -lang F#
   
   dotnet new sln
   dotnet sln add blazor
   dotnet sln add classlib
   
   cd blazorwasm
   dotnet add reference ../classlib
   ```
2. add some F# code that should not stack overflow with TCO but would otherwise
3. call it from the Blazor app
4. 
   ```pwsh
   cd ../blazor
   dotnet run -c Release
   ```

### Expected behavior

(See repro) Weather.razor L31 should not throw a `StackOverflowException`

### Actual behavior

(See repro) Weather.razor L31 throws a `StackOverflowException`

### Regression?

Around 2024-10-03, the exceptions would not be throw on `Release` configuration but they would on `Debug`. I am not sure if this was a regression at the time or not but it fixed my issue. Now it happens on all configurations.

### Known Workarounds

In theory, I could pass `--tailcalls-` to `fsc` to avoid emitting the `tail.` op, but the tail call is part of a library I am consuming and I do not want to setup a git submodule and rebuild the library.

### Configuration

```
dotnet --list-sdks
6.0.427 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
8.0.403 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
```

- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.26100.2033]
- x64
- Blazor: Microsoft Edge

### Other information

No matter whether I pass `true` or `false` for `BlazorWebAssemblyJiterpreter`, the exception is still thrown.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: So I'm assuming there is no problem with the application, right ?  This log indicates that an optimization fails so the performance of the app will be worse.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
Yes, this indicates that the jiterpreter failed and shut itself off automatically. The error indicates something went wrong with exception handling - invalid tag index 0 suggests that maybe the exception handling tag was missing? I haven't touched the EH code recently, but I believe @pavelsavara looked at it so he might have some ideas for how this could happen.

Is there anything unusual about your project, perhaps custom C files or linked in native libraries? I'm wondering whether relinking is causing the exception handling data to go missing.

nodes.author: Dona278
nodes.body:
@BrzVlad yes even with these errors it seems to work well. 
About performance instead: it is relative to a single piece of code or when this error occur the rest of the application will be affected?

@kg thanks for the info! 
The project is build with:
```
<WasmEnableThreads>false</WasmEnableThreads>
<WasmEnableSIMD>false</WasmEnableSIMD>
<WasmEnableExceptionHandling>false</WasmEnableExceptionHandling>
```
because otherwise on some mobile devices blazor don't start.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body: The EnableExceptionHandling option is the cause of this issue, most likely. In the past I went through some effort to ensure that it would work given that option but I must have missed something.

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: @kg Could this error be related to the interpreter optimizing out some clauses from the method ?

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body: No, the code being generated is a transition trampoline, the equivalent of jit_call_cb. The problem is that it's trying to create a 'catch' block and the type to catch is missing.

nodes.author: kg
nodes.body:
Please try following the instructions in https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/mono/jiterpreter.md#configuring-the-jiterpreter to disable specifically `jiterpreter-jit-call-enabled`. That should suppress this error and keep the rest of the jiterpreter working. If that doesn't work, also disable `jiterpreter-interp-entry-enabled`.

This would probably look like
```xml
<BlazorWebAssemblyRuntimeOptions>--no-jiterpreter-jit-call-enabled</BlazorWebAssemblyRuntimeOptions>
```

nodes.author: akoeplinger
nodes.body: Are you sure you need the WasmEnableExceptionHandling=false? which devices hit issues with this?

nodes.author: Dona278
pavelsavara
nodes.body:
> I believe pavelsavara looked at it so he might have some ideas for how this could happen.

I even made [changes](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/111033/files) in the Net10 about the way how we lift exception tag `___cpp_exception` from emscripten. 

We (still) only get the tag exported when `WasmEnableExceptionHandling` is true. And my change didn't change that conditional. 

Does `___cpp_exception` symbol make sense even when `WasmEnableExceptionHandling=false` ? 
If not, then jiterp should not be using it either.

If `___cpp_exception` makes sense with `-fexceptions` too, we should drop the condition on the `EXPORT_EXCEPTION_HANDLING_HELPERS`/`EmccExportedFunction`.

Note that `WasmEnableExceptionHandling=false` triggers re-link.

nodes.author: Dona278
nodes.body:
I just deployed a build without `WasmEnableExceptionHandling=false` and I didn't have issues on old mobile devices (on which I was able to do the tests regards issue which I mentioned with that flag) and the jit error seems to not appear anymore.
I think for dotnet the problem should be solved, but for now it's fine for me, thanks!

title: MONO_WASM: jit_call code generation failed in Blazor WASM project

author: lewing
body:
Evidence suggests that there is value in filling some more of the Vector and Unsafe intrinsics

- [ ] Add intrinsics for 128 bit vector types
    - [x] Use PackedSimd methods where they correspond directly to 128 bit Vector methods
    - [x] Use PackedSimd methods for Vector(128)? operators for direct matches
    - [ ] add implementations of .NET missing intrinsics using Wasm intrinsics directly
- [ ] Implement managed PackedSimd implementations of the Vector128 methods that have managed sse implementations
- [ ] recognize VectorMath hot paths
- [ ] implement missing instance intrinsic methods
- [ ] implement missing Unsafe intrinsics
    - [x] Bitcast
      - [x] AOT https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/115130
      - [x] Interpreter https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/115443
    - [ ] ReadUnaligned, WriteUnaligned

Crash log:

nodes.author: BrzVlad
nodes.body: This could be easily fixed by disabling generation of `MINT_LDFLDA_UNSAFE` / `MINT_MOV_P` during `CEE_LDFLDA` compilation, however this might regress performance for the common case and I don't believe the testcase is something relevant in practice.

title: [Apple mobile][mono] `GitHub_23791` runtime test crash in AOT-interpreter mode

title: System.Reflection.Metadata.ApplyUpdateTest.TestAddInstanceField fails after roslyn update in hotreload-utils

author: andrew-kulikov
body: ### Description I am porting a huge .NET application (a game written on a custom engine) to browser-wasm runtime. In release build we use AOT, and I noticed that in such configuration SBRK pointer slightly grows during app lifetime while managed heap size stays the same. Investigation with emscripten memory profiler helped me to find some problems, so listing them here. In our app we use Autofac, which uses expressions under the hood a lot (for example, [here](https://github.com/autofac/Autofac/blob/797c5cff0c3688e3a64c695805d1ab699f756db5/src/Autofac/Core/Activators/Reflection/ConstructorParameterBinding.cs#L182) and [here](https://github.com/autofac/Autofac/blob/797c5cff0c3688e3a64c695805d1ab699f756db5/src/Autofac/Features/GeneratedFactories/FactoryGenerator.cs#L177)). The typical use case with Autofac is - on feature launch we create a child scope and register feature-specific services in that scope. As the result each feature launch allocates from few hundred KB to few MB, most of them are compiled delegates and generic vtables. Newtonsoft.Json also [uses](https://github.com/JamesNK/Newtonsoft.Json/blob/96df2ab9c15334f5bf2bf530a6bc1d9cb33f0c77/Src/Newtonsoft.Json/Utilities/ExpressionReflectionDelegateFactory.cs#L58) expressions, but I assume they are cached for entire app lifetime. I played with expressions on wasm and found a few problems and/or unclear moments. Repo with reproduction samples can be found [here](https://github.com/andrew-kulikov/dotnetwasm-bench). #### 1. Dynamic code is not disabled by default in aot mode When `RunAOTCompilation` is set to true, `System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RuntimeFeature.IsDynamicCodeSupported` is still set to true, which causes expression compiler to emit new types on each expression compile. I found that is is set to true in sdk targets, but is not overriden in mono. https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/blob/8f65fb8192e4828338f87cedd19d9a41ace507b6/src/Tasks/Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks/targets/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.targets#L658-L661 I found that mono does support overriding this property https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/b86266dc5a2de9add4c34fcea78765cb0eed1ca9/src/mono/mono/mini/intrinsics.c#L2445-L2457, but on wasm it seems to be never executed. #### 2. Memory leaks even when dynamic code is disabled Sample code that leaks when dynamic code is enabled: ```cs [JSExport] public static async Task CompiledFuncExpressions(int count, bool doGc) { for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) { var objects = new List

nodes.author: lewing
nodes.body: mono Wasm AOT sets `IsDynamicCodeSupported == true` and `IsDynamicCodeCompiled == false` because that is what the runtime supports.

title: [wasm] [aot] Memory leak when interpreting expressions
